citations.narrative:
During the review of paperwork and records, it was noted that the acquisition and disposition records were incomplete. All
required information about where the animals were purchased or otherwise acquired from was unavailable at the time of
inspection. In addition, all required information for animals sold, transferred, or that otherwise left the facility was also
unavailable at the time of inspection. The facility was lacking acquisition records for the patagonian cavies, at least 1
lemur, and 1 kangaroo. No records existed for animals the facility recently sold/traded, including a camel, a kangaroo, and
a lemur. Appropriate documentation of regulated animals is essential for proper identification, to trace and track animals in
case of disease outbreak, and to ensure all parties that are required to be licensed have a current, valid license. Every
exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information
concerning animals, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor: name,
address, and USDA license number of the buyer or seller, date of purchase/trade, species, and number of animals in the
deal. The records shall include any offspring of any animal while in their possession or under their control. Correct from
4/15/25 forward

In both the ring-tailed lemur and spider monkey enclosures, multiple sharp points were creating hazards that could injure
the primates. In the lemur enclosure, wires used to secure panels were rusted and pointing into the enclosures. The
spider monkey enclosure is built around an old metal feed hopper and the bottom part of the feeder is rusted and jagged.
Additionally, the spider monkey has pulled down part of the wire panel, above where it is secured to the wood frame,
leaving sharp points directed in to the enclosure. Primates are inquisitive and like to manipulate the structures in their
cages; any sharp objects in the enclosure can cause injury. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so
that they have no sharp points or edges that could injure the nonhuman primates. Correct by 4/22/25

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility lacks an environmental enhancement plan for their primates. There is no plan, written or otherwise. The facility
replaces cage furnishings only when they break. Primates can experience mental distress when their environment is not
enriched. Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow and appropriate plan for environment enhancement, as directed
by the attending veterinarian. The plan must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations,
such as infants and juveniles, individually housed primates, and any primates showing signs of psychological distress.
Correct by 5/15/25

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility lacks an environmental enhancement plan for their birds. There is no plan, written or otherwise. The facility
replaces cage furnishings only when they break. Birds can experience mental distress when their environment is not
enriched. Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement, as
directed by the attending veterinarian. The plan must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special
considerations, such as chicks or fledglings, individually housed social species, and any birds showing signs of
psychological distress. Correct by 5/15/25
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
During the review of paperwork and records, it was noted that the acquisition and disposition records were incomplete. All 
required information about where the animals were purchased or otherwise acquired from was unavailable at the time of 
inspection. In addition, all required information for animals sold, transferred, or that otherwise left the facility was also 
unavailable at the time of inspection. The facility was lacking acquisition records for the patagonian cavies, at least 1 
lemur, and 1 kangaroo. No records existed for animals the facility recently sold/traded, including a camel, a kangaroo, and 
a lemur. Appropriate documentation of regulated animals is essential for proper identification, to trace and track animals in 
case of disease outbreak, and to ensure all parties that are required to be licensed have a current, valid license. Every 
exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information 
concerning animals, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under 
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor: name, 
address, and USDA license number of the buyer or seller, date of purchase/trade, species, and number of animals in the 
deal. The records shall include any offspring of any animal while in their possession or under their control. Correct from 
4/15/25 forward 
3.80(a)(2)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
In both the ring-tailed lemur and spider monkey enclosures, multiple sharp points were creating hazards that could injure 
the primates. In the lemur enclosure, wires used to secure panels were rusted and pointing into the enclosures. The 
spider monkey enclosure is built around an old metal feed hopper and the bottom part of the feeder is rusted and jagged. 
Additionally, the spider monkey has pulled down part of the wire panel, above where it is secured to the wood frame, 
leaving sharp points directed in to the enclosure. Primates are inquisitive and like to manipulate the structures in their 
cages; any sharp objects in the enclosure can cause injury. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so 
that they have no sharp points or edges that could injure the nonhuman primates. Correct by 4/22/25 
3.81 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.

The facility lacks an environmental enhancement plan for their primates. There is no plan, written or otherwise. The facility 
replaces cage furnishings only when they break. Primates can experience mental distress when their environment is not 
enriched. Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow and appropriate plan for environment enhancement, as directed 
by the attending veterinarian. The plan must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special considerations, 
such as infants and juveniles, individually housed primates, and any primates showing signs of psychological distress. 
Correct by 5/15/25 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The facility lacks an environmental enhancement plan for their birds. There is no plan, written or otherwise. The facility 
replaces cage furnishings only when they break. Birds can experience mental distress when their environment is not 
enriched. Exhibitors must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for environment enhancement, as 
directed by the attending veterinarian. The plan must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special 
considerations, such as chicks or fledglings, individually housed social species, and any birds showing signs of 
psychological distress. Correct by 5/15/25 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
